segments.text: Upon leaving the bank in the Offerdar center, Yehuda bumped into Yosef, who was just about to enter.
They shook hands firmly and asked about each other's well-being.
Yosef explained to Yehuda that he came to take care of some errands, and suddenly Yehuda said to him, I hope you're not angry that I let her stay in one of the rooms for the time being.
That's how it started.
But within two minutes she simply took over the whole abandoned area around and brought life back to the desert that had spread there for months.
I'm not doing anything with the house anyway, so for now, she's keeping it for me, or as she says, just for the meantime."
He smiled at Yosef gently, a bit embarrassed, and then added, Your daughter is something special.
Yosef was stunned.
He didn't know what to say.
He was sure that Leora was sleeping over on the weekends at Roushla, her new friend.
Or at the kaboots with Eric, her longtime buddy.
He had no idea she was staying at the pink house.
Just two weeks ago, she had a chance to tell him about it when they sat at the cafe at Jackie's and she didn't say a word.
He raised his eyes to Yehuda with an embarrassed, ashamed look, and Yehuda noticed the shock on his face, his paleness, perhaps even shame.
And sorry, Yosef, I was sure you knew.
Maybe she didn't want to upset you.
Listen.
I'm sitting here at Madan, and after you're done, I have to take you to see the house, so you understand what I'm talking about.
A short while later, they stood at the entrance to his pink house.
His foot hadn't set inside from the day he left.
A giant wound remained open in him from the departure, and he couldn't bring himself to see it again.
Even the male that would arrive at Carmela, the neighbor, he asked to send to his new address.

She knew that he came to Oshkolan from time to time to the clock center, mainly to settle matters, or to sit for a short while at the Madan cafe with this or that friend, and she would tell him on the phone, come visit Yosef.
Yes, sure, when I get a chance, he would brush her off, knowing he wouldn't be able to handle it in the near future.
He needed to recover from this blow that struck him, knowing he still didn't have the strength to face it.
But now, almost ten months after leaving the pink house, he stood at the entrance, immediately recognizing the path with the silver spirals, the pansy flowers, and seeing in amazement the sweet peas,
Climbing halfway up the trellis, someone had assembled in his place along the walls of the house.
He felt the pain in his heart.
Nothing reminded him more of Lucy than the sweet peas.
For a moment, he remembered how his daughter covered her mother in her flowers before she was covered with earth.
Yehuda approached the kitchen window ledge and pulled the key from its hiding place.

He opened the door and once he pushed it inward, Yosef stood rooted to the spot, amazed at the clean and groomed wonder with the tablecloth and the vase of flowers still blooming from two days ago when she was there.
Yehuda opened the shutters and a great light flooded the dining room and filled his paintings, all hung in their original places.
Only Lucy's portrait was moved closer to the bar as if wanting to draw her near.
Through the glass doors facing the garden, he saw the blossoming garden, the mowed grass and the huge china berry tree shading everything from above.
For a moment he was dizzy, feeling he couldn't take it.
He clutched the armrest of the armchair and collapsed into it, closing his eyes tightly and covering them with his hands.
Yehuda looked at him with pity.
Perhaps he made a mistake bringing him here.
He was sure it would make him happy, and now it seemed too painful.
Yehuda didn't know that Yosef hadn't even walked by the house since he left.
Deep inside, he understood that Yosef's pain also stemmed from the fact that his daughter, Leora, didn't tell him any of this, and he didn't understand the reason for this rift between them.
After all, they were inseparable.
Father and daughter.
Everyone knew that.
She used to follow him everywhere as a child and sit with him or on his lap in his friend's parliament.
Even when she grew up, he was so proud of her.
And suddenly like this?
Well, he thought, it's better not to get into it.
These are their matters.
He went to the bar, took a beer bottle from the fridge, uncorked it, and handed it to Yosef.
Only after taking two sips and somewhat recovering did he dare to say to him, the house was so neglected.
For months I didn't touch anything.
Everything was dusty.
The garden almost completely withered and Leora came and simply breathed life into it here.
She cleaned and scrubbed and for hours she took care of the garden, weeded and brought seedlings from Shraga from the nursery.
And one day when she wasn't there, he came and arranged the trellis for the sweet peas.
Carmella told me,
I pass by here sometimes when she's in the army, just like that, just to enjoy this wonder that's come back to life.
She's been coming here on weekends for a few months now.
She came when Zevik passed away and went in to see what was going on here and found me sitting in the armchair.
After politely asking about my well-being, she actually scolded me that I hadn't done anything with the house for months.
I saw that she was really shocked that everything remained in its place as it was, dusty and looking like a ghost house.
I started to stammer, told her that for now I have no idea what I'll do with the house and would probably sell it as separate houses, like it was originally.
Then, after a long moment of silence, she almost whispered if I minded her staying in one of the rooms.
Just for the meantime, until I decide.
In a second, I put my hand in my pocket and gave her the key.
Told her to duplicate it and leave me one copy on the kitchen window ledge behind the manchella.
That closes the shutter.
And that's it.
I came after three days and found a new house.
clean, shiny, the windows sparkling, the garden watered, and on one of the tables even a bouquet of chrysanthemums she had picked in the field across and put into a beer glass.
And the paintings all hung one by one in their places, as if they had never been taken down from the walls.
For a moment I stood amazed and then out of the corner of my eye,
I saw a letter leaning on a jar on the reception counter on which was written for Yehuda.
She left me a touching and apologetic letter.
It turns out she rented two rooms to soldiers who wanted to stay, and in the jar by the entrance she left the payment she received, minus a few pennies she took for herself.
Of course I didn't touch her money.
I've met her only twice more since.
I made an arrangement with Claude from Aphrodare that she would pay the small monthly lease fee, so she would feel she was paying rent.
And that way, if someone came to stay over, she'd feel comfortable keeping the money.
And listen, I had no idea she knew how to cook.
Yosef raised his moist eyes to him.
Yehuda had been talking to him for a while, and it seemed that only part of the words penetrated him.
The whole situation shook him completely, presenting him with a grim mirror image of himself, and on the other hand, of his daughter managing bravely on her own.
Suddenly he noticed the blue painting she loved so much, and only then did his eyes wander and stop at the abandoned corner of the piano.
You're right, she really is something special, my daughter, he said suddenly, and I didn't know she knew how to cook either.
only much after Lucy passed away.
When Fortuna no longer came, did she suddenly take over the kitchen as if she was getting direct instructions from Lucy into her ear?
There is something completely mystical between those two.
She was always a contemplative child.
You could see her eyes growing and the wheels spinning in her head, observing and absorbing in almost every field.
And here in the moment of truth, everything that was imprinted in her over the years came out, maybe also everything.
We instilled in her independence and freedom and not fearing difficulties.
And if I may say, also culture and manners, I very much want to believe that I have a part in it too, not only Lucy.
He ended the sentence with a somewhat painful tone.
Suddenly he just wanted to get out of there.
Yehuda, I really thank you for your generosity and for trusting her.
She needed a corner of her own to lay her head, perhaps also her soul.
Things didn't go so well between her and my partner, and frankly, not so well between her and me.
It probably won't last for a long time.
It's very hard to fill shoes as big as Lucy's, maybe not even possible.
For now, I'm giving it a bit more chance.
Thank you very much, and just please promise me that if there is any problem, no matter how small, you'll call me."
He rose slowly from the armchair, cast a long look around, and for a moment again his eyes rested on the abandoned corner of the piano.
He closed his eyes and then opened them, shook Yahuda's hand, said goodbye, and went on his way, knowing exactly what he had to do.
